newsitem.title: GERMANY: Bonn again tops up German Labour Office budget.
newsitem.headline: Bonn again tops up German Labour Office budget.

text.p: The German Federal Labour Office, its jobless benefits scheme struggling to cope with record post-war unemployment, has received an extra top-up of state cash to balance its 1996 budget, parliament said on Tuesday.
The Bonn government informed parliament that the Labour Office had received an extra 2.7 billion marks ($1.70 billion), coming on top of an earlier transfer of seven billion marks in the autumn.

Instead of originally budgeted transfers of 4.3 billion marks, total transfers to the Labour Office for last year came out at some 14 billion marks. Billions more had to be paid to fund federally financed unemployment-assistance schemes.
Germany's unemployment insurance scheme represents one of the main risks to Finance Minister Theo Waigel's bid to control borrowing and qualify this year for European monetary union, planned in 1999.
In drafting his 1997 budget -- which foresees an overall budget deficit of 2.5 percent of gross domestic product -- Waigel planned the Labour Office subsidy at 4.1 billion marks.
The budget deficit is likely to be around four percent for 1996, well above the three percent ceiling envisaged in the Maastricht treaty.

Ursula Engelen-Kefer, deputy leader of the DGB German Trade Union Federation, told Tuesday's Frankfurter Rundschau newspaper that additional federal transfers this year would have to be between seven and 12 billion marks. Engelen-Kefer sits on the Labour Office board.
Under the German constitution, the federal government is responsible for ensuring that state social security agencies are fully funded.
